preamble.p: dCache follows a two dimensional release system. Every couple of months we produce a feature release. Feature releases have version numbers 1.9.x-1, where x is a positive integer. Each feature release is followed up by a number of maintenance releases containing bug fixes or high priority feature tweaks. Maintenance releases for release 1.9.x-1 have version numbers 1.9.x-y, for y being an integer larger than 1.
The releases available from this page are no longer supported. Sites should not deploy these versions. Instead, please install a supported version of dCache.

description.p: dCache 4.1 features the following highlights and architectural improvements:

ul.li: This release of dCache introduces Kafka as a message transport, for now in Billing, as a new approach to external messaging.
Various administrative tasks are now possible for users with the admin role using frontend.
The frontend REST API is documented with Swagger, allowing the auto-generation of clients.
The frontend also now comes with a built-in web-browser based Swagger client.
The configuration of several components has been simplified.

description.p: dCache v4.1 requires a JVM supporting Java 8.
dCache 4.0 features the following highlights and architectural improvements:

ul.li: dCache-StAR now supports PostgreSQL servers on non-standard ports.
dCache now supports RFC 3230-style Want-Digest headers. These allow clients to request specific checksumming algorithms.
gPlazma may be configured so that plugins cooperate in building a list of gids for an authenticated user.
Pools can now be configured to calculate several checksums for any uploaded file at once.

description.p: dCache v4.0 requires a JVM supporting Java 8.
dCache 3.2 features the following highlights and architectural improvements:

ul.li: Support for macaroons in WebDAV door.
Switch to systemd-compatible scripts on Debian systems.
OpenID connect support for frontend.
TLS encryption is introduced for domain communication.

description.p: dCache v3.2 requires a JVM supporting Java 8.
dCache 3.1 features the following highlights and architectural improvements:

ul.li: Plenty of NFS door improvements.
Chimera can track file upload status.
OpenID connect support for WebDAV 3rd party copy.
Allow regular expression matching of storage units in resilience manager.

description.p: dCache v3.1 requires a JVM supporting Java 8.
dCache 3.0 features the following highlights and architectural improvements:

ul.li: Production-ready support for high availability setups and rolling updates.
Automatic detection of PostgreSQL master.
Support the HAProxy proxy protocol.
Self describing billing files.
Pool manager setup is stored in ZooKeeper.
Pool manager read-only state is stored in setup file and ZooKeeper.
New experimental support for Ceph
New performance cost calculation for improved stability of hot spot replication.
Batching of flush to tape can be disabled.
Mover queues can be created at runtime.
Abort upload when SRM TURL is invalidated.
Allow xrootd clients to select mover queues.

description.p: dCache v3.0 requires a JVM supporting Java 8.
In addition to the usual improvements and bug fixes, dCache 2.16 features the following highlights:

ul.li: New experimental RESTful API.
New experimental end user web interface called dCacheView.
New experimental support for redundant cell communication using multiple message brokers.
New resilience service for managing file replicas. Will eventually replace the replica manager.
New experimental support for replicable services.
Scalable SRM frontend service.
Limited OpenID Connect support.

description.p: dCache v2.16 requires a JVM supporting Java v8.
In addition to the usual improvements and bug fixes, dCache 2.15 features the following highlights:

ul.li: Improved glob patterns,
More robust handling of over load situations,
fsck for Chimera on upgrade,
Reduced storage requirements for Chimera,
Chimera can store multiple checksum for a file,
Admin shell documentation updates,
gPlazma restriction attributes,
Set ACLs through DCAP.
Pool startup improvements.

description.p: dCache v2.15 requires a JVM supporting Java v8.
In addition to the usual improvements and bug fixes, dCache 2.14 features the following highlights:

ul.li: Significant performance and storage space improvements in Chimera,
OCSP support and EUGRIDPMA name space support,
Concurrent request processing in gPlazma,
Pool group patterns in admin shell,
Improved UberFTP support,
WebDAV door can report file locality,
Fair share scheduling for SRM transfers,
SRM database managed by liquibase,
Configurable kXR_Qconfig support for xrootd.

description.p: dCache v2.14 requires a JVM supporting Java v8.
In addition to the usual improvements and bug fixes, dCache 2.13 features the following highlights:

ul.li: major overhaul of admin interface,
robust internal delete and flush notification,
info-provider generates timestamps on published objects,
pool migration module maintains last-access-time,
pool implements strict LRU garbage collection,
improved shutdown in space-manager,
Reserving space from a linkgroup may be authorised by GID,
better scalability in FTP doors,
new admin commands for nfs service,
FTS-specific information recorded,
xrootd doors support the protocol's asynchronous open,
support for custom HTTP response headers.

description.p: dCache v2.13 requires a JVM supporting Java v8.
In addition to the usual improvements and bug fixes, dCache 2.12 features the following highlights:

ul.li: New site description property to add local branding.
Admin shell supports Ctrl-C to interrupt commands.
Alarms service can share domains with other services.
Improved attribute handling in Chimera.
Shorter session identifiers.
FTP and DCAP cell names are unique across restarts.
Info provider publishes all global network interfaces.
Improved login broker registration and SRM door selection, including improved IPv6 support.
Improved and more robust NFS proxy mode.
On the fly checksum calculation for NFS and xrootd.
Improved nearline storage Service Provider Interface for more flexible drivers.
Precomputed repository statistics in pools.
HTTP and xrootd uploads block until post-processing completes.
Reduced memory consumption in pools using Berkeley DB.
Site specific srmPing attributes.
Parameterized WebDAV templates.
More uniform access logs.
Localized timestamps in pinboard.
Improved bash completion.

description.p: dCache v2.12 requires a JVM supporting Java v8.
In addition to the usual improvements and bug fixes, dCache 2.11 features the following highlights:

ul.li: Faster deletion speeds.
Better integration of alarms service, easier configuration, and predefined alarms.
Multiple GIDs in kpwd.
Less clutter in GLUE 2 StorageShare.
Improved pool response during HSM request bursts.
Reduced latency on write.
Automatic throttling of SRM request rate when database request queue is full.
Decoupling of transfer managers from srm database.

description.p: dCache v2.11 requires a JVM supporting either Java v7 or Java v8.
In addition to the usual improvements and bug fixes, dCache 2.10 features the following highlights:

ul.li: Improved SRM scheduling and protection of other components.
Reimplemented webadmin active transfers page.
Improved support for HTTP and HTTPS 3rd-party transfers.
Added support for 3rd-party transfers through WebDAV.
Improved support for HTTP 3rd-party transfers through SRM.
Improved default HTML rendering in WebDAV.
Added JSON support for info.

description.p: dCache v2.10 requires a JVM supporting either Java v7 or Java v8.
In addition to the usual improvements and bug fixes, dCache 2.9 features the following highlights:

ul.li: Reduces chimera overhead on file creation and file open.
New database connection pool for more robust database interaction.
Supports NFS 4 (without parallel NFS)
DCAP clients can now be forced to do I/O through a mounted NFS 4 file system.
Much improved performance and standard compliance for NFS 4.
Improves support for meta data in FTP.
Improves FTP client compatibility.
Implements FTP delayed passive, allowing IPv6 FTP transfers without proxying.
New pool manager partition for transfer buffers (e.g. import and export pools).
Improves ROOT compatibility for HTTP access.
GridSite delegation support for SRM.
Unique TURLs for SRM upload for improved error handling.
Improves transfer protocol negotiation for SRM.
Reduces impact of SRM restart.
Improves protocol support for xrootd.
More flexible tape integration.

description.p: In addition to the usual improvements and bug fixes, dCache 2.8 features the following highlights:

ul.li: Rewrite of space manager service
New chimera command that replacing chimera-cli and provides an interactive shell
File and directory creation time now stored in chimera
File Access-Latency, Retention-Policy and Checksums exposed as WebDAV properties
Support for WLCG federated HTTP
IPv6 support for FTP
Support for an access log; SRM updated to log client requests
Report checksums through NFS dot commands

description.p:
In addition to the usual improvements and bug fixes, dCache 2.7 focuses on:
New consistent naming scheme for configuration properties.
Billing plots now generated by httpd, which implies that billing service and httpd service are allowed to run on separate machines.
Possibility to specify multiple poolgroups as target poolgroups in migration module.
Chimera now supports the set-gid bit on directories to allow the group owner of new entries to be inherited from the directory.
Added possibility for pool to callout to external health check script.
Pools now implement rate-limiting in the 'sweeper purge' command to avoid pnfsmanager overload caused by high deletion rate.
Support for htpasswd files.
SRM has been extensivly cleaned up.

In addition to the usual improvements and bug fixes, dCache 2.6 focuses on:
NFS with ACL and read-only exports
webadmin pages with all their improvements are default
xrootd and http movers use less resources on pools
StAR records update
prototype of JSON API
new command to find out file locality

p.strong: If you upgrade from dCache 2.2 to dCache 2.6, please read the preliminary version of the Ultimate Golden Release Upgrade Guide carefully.

Sites upgrading to 2.6.x and runnig postgresql < 9.2 should be aware that due to an unfortunate behaviour of postgresql the automated database schema migration which is applied on startup of dCache may take a lot of time (e.g. 3 hours for 20 million files).

description.p:
In addition to the usual improvements and bug fixes, dCache 2.5 focuses on:
Support for certificates with SHA2 checksum

p.strong: Sites upgrading to 2.5.x and runnig postgresql < 9.2 should be aware that due to an unfortunate behaviour of postgresql the automated database schema migration which is applied on startup of dCache may take a lot of time (e.g. 3 hours for 20 million files).
Please note that due to a regression introduced in dCache 2.5.0, which has been fixed in dCache 2.5.2, dCache 2.5.2 is not compatible with dCache 2.5.0 or dCache 2.5.1.

description.p:
In addition to the usual improvements and bug fixes, dCache 2.4 focuses on:
Support for last access time on reads
Admin interface may use private gPlazma instance
gPlazma reports when login fails due to misconfiguration
Configurable path of certificate locations
billingDB supports pool's cache hits recording

p.strong: Please notice, that starting version 2.4 requires Java-7.

description.strong: Sites upgrading to 2.4.x and runnig postgresql < 9.2 should be aware that due to an unfortunate behaviour of postgresql the automated database schema migration which is applied on startup of dCache may take a lot of time (e.g. 3 hours for 20 million fi les).

description.p:
In addition to the usual improvements and bug fixes, dCache 2.3 focuses on:
Support for redirect on HTTP PUT.
The Chimera database schema is now managed.
Webadmin as part of the standard dCache web pages.
Removal of legacy systems to allow new functionality.
Improved compatibility with databases other than PostgreSQL.
If you upgrade from dCache 1.9.12 to dCache 2.3, please read the Upgrade Instructions and the instructions how to migrate from the/opt layout to the FHS compliant layout.
description.strong: Sites upgrading to 2.3.2 should be aware that due to an unfortunate behaviour of postgresql the automated database schema migration which is applied on startup of dCache may take a lot of time (e.g. 3 hours for 20 million files). We hope to have this fixed soon and recommend to think carefully about an upgrade to 2.3.2.

description.p:
In addition to the usual improvements and bug fixes, dCache 2.2 focuses on:
gPlazma 1 implemented as a plugin for gPlazma2
Java Authentication and Authorization Service (JAAS) based password authentication
Default partition type in the PoolManager is WAAS
NFSv4.1 door shows some statistic information
Added renaming to FTP implementation
Added support for change mode, owner and group of a directory tag
SRM always listen for SSL connections
Added login monitoring to gPlazma2
If you upgrade from dCache 1.9.12 to dCache 2.2, please read the Upgrade Instructions and the instructions how to migrate from the/opt layout to the FHS compliant layout.

strong.p: Due to the switch to jglobus2 in dCache 2.2.16 the xrootd4j-backport plugin does NOT work with dCache 2.2.16 and later and prevents grid-like doors and gPlazma from working correctly. Please upgrade to dCache 2.6 to use the name space mapping plugins. Alternatively stay with dCache 2.2.15 (without SHA2 support).

description.p:
In addition to the usual improvements and bug fixes, dCache 2.1 focuses on:
NIS plugin for gPlazma.
Keberos support for NFS.
ACL query and update through NFS 4.
Production ready webadmin.
Color highlighting in admin shell.
Tab completion in admin shell.
SSH2 support for admin shell.
Visualization of billing data.
EMI support in GLUE info provider.
Please note, that this is the last release series with packages in /opt. You can mix FHS and /opt based packages on a single installation. This will provide a migration path for big installations.

In addition to the usual improvements and bug fixes, dCache 2.0 focuses on:
introduced caching of id mapping results in NFSv4
Basic Auth support in webdav interface
added nsswitch and krb5 pugggins for gplazma2
acl cell merged into PnfsManager
dropped support for legasy commands in PoolManager
selectable and pluggable selection algorithms in partition manager
p2p uses http instaed of dcap

In addition to the usual improvements and bug fixes, dCache 1.9.13 focuses on:
Reduced latency in pool selection and pinning.
Reduced latency in single file listing through SRM.
Continous background checksum verification in pools.
Support SRM_FILE_UNAVAILABLE in SRM.
Improved throughput and reduced latency in Chimera.
POSIX compliant lookup permissions checks for Chimera.
Space manager database performance improvements.
SRM can optionally skip pinning for ONLINE files.
SRM can optionally work without pin manager in installations without tape.
Plain text FTP can use gPlazma for authentication.

In addition to the usual improvements and bug fixes, dCache 1.9.12 focuses on:
Completing the transition to the new configuration system and improving the script to migrate old configurations.
Adding GLUE 2 support.
Replacing the pin manager with a faster and more robust implementation.
Extending the dcache script.
Adding HTTP support to third party srmCopy transfers.
Adding proxy certificate and VOMS support to the HTTP/WebDAV door.
Reducing file open latency.
gPlazma 2 with ARGUS black listing (missing from initial release).

In addition to the usual improvements and bug fixes, dCache 1.9.11 focuses on:
Pool Scalability
GSI Authentication for XROOTD
SRM over HTTPS

In addition to the usual improvements and bug fixes, dCache 1.9.10 focuses on:
Improving ease of administration with a new logging framework, a new web based admin interface and pool rebalancing tools; and
improving SRM, NFS and xrootd scalability.

In addition to the usual improvements and bug fixes, dCache 1.9.9 focuses on cleaning the code base for authorization handling, adding support for several new xrootd requests, cleaning the code base for mover queue handling in pools.

1.9.8 further cleans up the configuration system, refines the WebDAV implementation, improves authorization in the xrootd door, improves configuration of FTP proxy behaviour, improves JMS based deployments, further simplifies first time deployments, and improves authorization of implicit space reservation.
Please note :
dCache 1.9.8 is not compatible with 1.9.5 pools. dCache 1.9.9 restores compatibility with 1.9.5 pools.

The main focus area of this release is to let go of old baggage. The internal changes in dCache 1.9.7 are small, however many configuration files have change, libraries have been upgraded, and deprecated components have been removed. Please read the release notes carefully when upgrading: Simply installing the new RPM will not be enough.
Since configuration files have changed, the first chapters of the current version of the dCache book no longer apply to dCache 1.9.7. We will update the dCache book in the near future.

The main focus areas of the 1.9.6 release are the addition of a WebDAV door, complete ACL support in the SRM, the ability to easily move cells between domains, and experimental Terracotta support in the SRM door

The 1.9.5 series of dCache releases will be supported for the duration of the 2009-2010 LHC run. In keeping with the other 1.9.n-series releases, no new features will be added to the 1.9.5-series of release, only bug-fixes. Versions of dCache with new features will still be available during the LHC run but as part of future major releases however these later releases will be supported for two major releases, in keeping with the current dCache support model.

li.font: This release is expected to be maintained throughout the first LHC data taking run.

ul.li: The main focus areas of the 1.9.5 release are optimisations and polish ahead of LHC data taking.
And as usual, please make yourself familiar with the release notes.

In addition to the 1.9.5 release notes, make sure that you follow the instructions on how to configure the LinkGroupAuthorization file in the 1.9.2 notes as those instructions are now enforced more strictly.
Many thanks to our beta tests (NDGF), who exposed the following issues :
1.9.5-1 suffers from a dead lock in the SRM frontend on high load. The problem is fixed with 1.9.5-2
In 1.9.5-1/2 the Information Provider module stops after a short while of activity. The team is investigating.
The SRM service in dCache 1.9.5-18 gets stuck after some minutes of operation.

description.p: The main focus areas of the 1.9.4 release are access control for staging from tape, a more scalable xrootd redirector, and a few performance improvements in Chimera.

ul.li: 1.9.4-2 This version does not contain the leak found in 1.9.1-10, 1.9.2-9, and 1.9.4-1. The leak requires a manual cleanup procedure after upgrade. Consult the release notes for details about the procedure.
1.9.4-1 A leak was found in the SRM causing excessive memory usage. We recommend not to install this version on a production system.
1.9.4-1 The SRM door contains a security vulnerability. This is fixed in 1.9.4-2.

description.p: dCache 1.9.3 is a feature release. The main focus areas of the 1.9.3 release are ACL support, NFS 4.1 support and asynchronous srmLs support. Other highlights include further refactoring of the pool code, first steps to refactor the pool manager, and support for using JMS for communication between dCache cells.

ul.li: <= 1.9.3-2 The SRM door contains a security vulnerability. This is fixed in 1.9.3-3.

li.strong: With 1.9.2 up to and including patch 5 you may observe a degradation in the performance of the PnfsManager. This is fixed with 1.9.2-6.

ul.li: Please make yourself familiar with the 1.9.2 release notes before installing this release.
We strongly discourage people from installing 1.9.2-3.
<= 1.9.2-8 The SRM door contains a security vulnerability. This is fixed in 1.9.2-9.
1.9.2-9 A leak was found in the SRM causing excessive memory usage. We recommend not to install this version of a production system.

1.9.2-10 This release contains two versions of the same library by mistake. This results in authentication failing when gPlazma is configured to use a SASL or XACLS interface, as with a GUMS server. We recommend not to install this version on a production system.
1.9.1-10 A leak was found in the SRM causing excessive memory usage. We recommend not to install this version of a production system.
<= 1.9.1-9 The SRM door contains a security vulnerability. This is fixed in 1.9.1-10.
1.9.1-1 to 1.9.1-3: The pools do not work correctly with SrmSpaceManager: all files are accounted for with size 0.
1.9.1-2: In case of p2p, stage failures and some transfer failures, over allocation is freed twice and thus break pool accounting.
1.9.1-2: Migration module jobs move to the FINISHED state until the list of files to transfer has been generated. As a consequence, -target=pgroup and -target=link do not work.
1.9.1-2: When under load, the migration module may trigger a bounce loop in dCache.
1.9.1-2: Migration jobs may in some cases resurrect from the CANCELLING or SUSPENDED states.
<1.9.0-7: The replica manager does not work with 1.9.1 pools.

end-note.p: Release notes for older releases are also available (1.9.1-3, 1.9.1-2 and 1.9.1-1).

ul.li: 1.9.0 releases are no longer supported.
<1.9.0-7: The replica manager does not work with 1.9.1 pools.
